Verse:
There are six kinds of truths.
Discussion:
There are six kinds of truths: 1. conventional truth, 2. ultimate truth, 3. truth of suffering, 4. truth of accumulation, 5. truth of cessation, 6. truth of the path.
Conventional truth refers to the collection of names, phrases, and syllables, and all verbal expressions based on their meanings, as well as the meanings understood based on those expressions.
It also refers to the minds and mental factors obtained in the world, as well as the meanings that they cognize.
Ultimate truth refers to the wisdom of the noble ones, the meanings cognized by them, and the associated minds, mental factors, and so forth.
The truth of suffering is of two kinds:
1. that included in conventional truth, and 2. that included in ultimate truth.
That included in conventional truth is as stated in the sÅ«tras:

The suffering of birth, the suffering of old age, the suffering of sickness, the suffering of death, the suffering of being separated from what is loved, the suffering of encountering what is hated, the suffering of not being able to obtain what one desires.
As for what is subsumed by the truth of ultimate meaning, as explained in the sutras:
In brief, all five appropriated aggregates are suffering.
As for the truth of the origin [of suffering], there are four kinds:
1. Complete subsumption, 2. Superior subsumption, 3. Subsumption by the conventional truth, 4. Subsumption by the truth of ultimate meaning.
As for complete subsumption, it refers to all the afflictions and karma in the three realms, all of which are called the truth of the origin [of suffering].

As for superior subsumption, it refers to the craving that arises in relation to the self and objects that have already been obtained or not yet obtained, the craving for continued existence, the craving that accompanies joy, and the craving for various things, all of which are called the truth of the origin [of suffering].
As for subsumption by the conventional truth, if a cause can give rise to the truth of suffering subsumed by the conventional truth.
As for subsumption by the truth of ultimate meaning, if a cause can give rise to the truth of suffering subsumed by the truth of ultimate meaning.
As for the truth of cessation, there are also four kinds, as explained above.
Complete inclusion refers to completely including the truth of accumulation without remainder, abandoning, expelling, exhausting, detaching from desire, extinguishing, and ceasing.

Superior inclusion refers to superiorly including the truth of accumulation without remainder, abandoning, as explained in detail.ğŸ”½Inclusion in the conventional truth refers to the truth of accumulation included in the conventional truth without remainder, abandoning, as explained in detail.
Inclusion in the ultimate truth refers to the truth of accumulation included in the ultimate truth without remainder, abandoning, as explained in detail.
As for the truth of the path, there are also four kinds, as explained above.
Complete inclusion refers to all the factors of enlightenment.
Superior inclusion refers to the eightfold noble path.

Inclusion in the conventional truth refers to the truths of suffering, accumulation, and cessation included in the conventional truth, in order to thoroughly know them, to permanently eliminate them, and to realize them.

As for all the holy paths being included in the ultimate truth, it means that in the case of the truths of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and path that are included in the ultimate truth, in order to thoroughly know them, it is explained in detail in this way.

As for the meaning of the four noble truths of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and path, if it is the case that the holy wisdom practices here, then this place of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and path is the truth, because all the holy ones consider this to be the truth, therefore it is called the noble truth.
Having explained the truths in this way, I will now explain their basis.
The verse says:
The basis is of eight kinds and two kinds.
The treatise says:
There are eight kinds of basis.
What are the eight?
Namely, the four meditations and the four formless [absorptions].
There are also two kinds.
What are the two?
Namely, the first meditation is of two kinds, worldly and supramundane, up to the sphere of nothingness is also of two kinds, worldly and supramundane;
The sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception is only worldly.

The mundane first trance is that which is attained by means of the mundane path, by the contemplation of the teaching of the superior dharma that is free from the desire of the realm of desire, or by taking as its object the superior instruction that is free from that, by the cultivation of the burning of the mind, etc., and by the attainment of the transmutation of the support, but because it does not deeply penetrate the meaning of that which is to be known, it is not able to eternally eliminate the propensities and the support of the passions of its own stage. It is the dharma of retrogression.

It is the support of the mind and mental activities of the samÄdhi of its own stage. As is the case with the mundane first trance, so is it with the mundane sphere of neither conception nor nonconception, etc. Each takes as its object the superior teaching that is free from the desire of the lower stage, and so on as explained above.

As for the supramundane first meditation, it means that one previously entered the first meditation with such practices, such appearances, and such characteristics in the mind, but now one does not enter with such practices, such appearances, and such characteristics in the mind. However, one contemplates the dharmas included in form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness as being like a disease, like a boil, like an arrow, obstructive, impermanent, suffering, empty, and non-self, or else one contemplates suffering as suffering, accumulation as accumulation, cessation as cessation, and the path as the path, or else one contemplates suchness, the nature of dharmas, and the ultimate reality.
In this way, having contemplated the dharmas as being like a disease up to the ultimate reality, one's mind becomes frightened and terrified of these dharmas.
Having become frightened and terrified, one's mind abides absorbed in the realm of immortality, or one's mind abides absorbed in suchness, the nature of dharmas, and the ultimate reality.

In this state, the nondiscriminating cognition, the mind and mental factors associated with it, and the basis of support that has been transformed, by penetrating deeply into the meaning of the knowable, are able to permanently eliminate the latent tendencies and are no longer the basis of all afflictions, and are the irreversible Dharma.
This is called the supramundane first concentration up to the sphere of nothingness.
It should be extensively explained that there are four kinds of concentrations and formless attainments:
1. Defiled, 2. pure, 3. establishment, 4. purification.
As for the defiled, it refers to deeply craving the higher concentrations, views, pride, and doubt.
Craving refers to ten kinds:

The first is the enjoyment of the mind of co-arising, the second is the enjoyment of the mind arisen from discrimination, the third is the enjoyment of the mind of one's own stage, the fourth is the enjoyment of the mind of other stages, the fifth is the enjoyment of the past, the sixth is the enjoyment of the future, the seventh is the enjoyment of the present, the eighth is the enjoyment of the inferior, the ninth is the enjoyment of the middling, and the tenth is the enjoyment of the superior.
Pure means pure and uncontaminated.
Pure means there are three kinds:
First, because of attraction, second, because of higher refinement, and third, because of being included in the purity that removes defilements and is capable.
Uncontaminated means this is also of three kinds:
First, uncontaminated supramundane, second, uncontaminated as its outflow, and third, uncontaminated as liberation.
Establishment means this is also of four kinds:
First, establishing access concentration, second, establishing fundamental concentration, third, establishing concentration, and fourth, establishing birth.
Establishing access concentration and fundamental concentration means as it is said in the sutra:

That is to say, this body is moistened by the joy and pleasure born of separation, thoroughly moistened, thoroughly delighted, and thoroughly permeated, this is called the preliminary stage of the first meditation.
As the sutra says:
In this very body, there is not the slightest part that is not completely filled with the joy and pleasure born of separation, this is called the fundamental stage of the first meditation.
As the sutra says:
In this very body, the joy and pleasure born of concentration moisten, thoroughly moisten, thoroughly delight, and thoroughly permeate, this is called the preliminary stage of the second meditation.
As the sutra says:
In this very body, there is not the slightest part that is not completely filled with the joy and pleasure born of concentration, this is called the fundamental stage of the second meditation.
As the sutra says:
In this very body, the pleasure of being free from joy moistens, thoroughly moistens, thoroughly delights, and thoroughly permeates, this is called the preliminary stage of the third meditation.
As the sutra says:
In this very body, there is no place whatsoever that is not pervaded by the bliss of joy, this is called the fundamental third concentration.
As the sutra says:
In this very body, with a pure mind and a bright mind, one dwells replete with mental resolve, this is called the access concentration of the fourth meditation.
As the sutra says:
In this very body, there is no place whatsoever that is not pervaded by the pure mind and the bright mind, this is called the fundamental fourth concentration.
As the sutra says:

Because one transcends all conceptual thoughts of form, because one extinguishes all conceptual thoughts of resistance, because one does not attend to conceptual thoughts of various kinds, one enters the sphere of infinite space, where space is boundless, this is called the access concentration of the sphere of infinite space.
As the sutra says:
Dwelling replete with it, this is called the fundamental sphere of infinite space.
As the sutra says:
Transcending all the sphere of infinite space, entering the sphere of infinite consciousness, this is called the preliminary stage of the sphere of infinite consciousness.
As the sutra says:
Abiding in fullness refers to the fundamental stage of the sphere of infinite consciousness.
As the sutra says:
Transcending all the sphere of infinite consciousness, entering the sphere of nothingness, this is called the preliminary stage of the sphere of nothingness.
As the sutra says:
Abiding in fullness refers to the fundamental stage of the sphere of nothingness.
As the sutra says:
Transcending all the sphere of nothingness, entering the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, this is called the preliminary stage of the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
As the sutra says:
Abiding in fullness refers to the fundamental stage of the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
As for establishing concentration, as the sutra says:
Because of being free from desires and evil unwholesome states, with initial and sustained thought, joy and happiness, one abides in the first meditative absorption.

Free from desires means either taking as the dominant condition the teachings that are the basis for being free from desires for the desire realm, or having already taken as one's object of cognition those teachings that are the basis for being free from desires, one eliminates the defilements of the desire realm.
Free from evil unwholesome states means eliminating the defilements of actions in the desire realm, which are dharmas that can lead one to fall into evil destinies, and are therefore called evil.
They are able to obstruct what is wholesome, and are therefore called unwholesome.

Initial thought refers to the initial thought that is able to counteract two kinds of defilements: the initial thought of renunciation, the initial thought of non-hatred, and the initial thought of non-harmfulness.

Sustained thought refers to the sustained thought that is able to counteract two kinds of defilements: the sustained thought of renunciation, the sustained thought of non-hatred, and the sustained thought of non-harmfulness.
Free means that by cultivating the antidotes, one eliminates the obstacles that are to be eliminated and attains the transformation of the basis.
Arisen means that which arises from this.

Joy is the mental pleasure, mental courage, mental satisfaction, and mental pliancy of one who has attained the transmutation of the support and is based on the evolving consciousnesses. It is categorized as feeling.
Pleasure is the feeling of pleasure and satisfaction in the support of one who has attained the transmutation of the support and is based on the Älaya consciousness. It is categorized as feeling.
First means that among the various samÄdhis, this one is the first in order.

DhyÄna means that, based on the transmutation of the support, one is able to eliminate the dharmas defiled by the realm of desire, and it is the support of applied and sustained thought, joy, and pleasure. It is the one-pointedness of mind.
Complete means cultivation.
Abiding means freely and at will entering, abiding in, and emerging from .
Also, as a scripture says,

Because applied and sustained thought are stilled, because internal serenity increases, and because the mind becomes unified, the second dhyÄna arises, which is free of applied and sustained thought, has joy and pleasure born of concentration, and is complete in all its parts.

The cessation of applied and sustained thought means that, either by the power of teachings that transcend the desire for the first dhyÄna, or by taking those teachings as objects, the applied and sustained thought of the first dhyÄna stage ceases and no longer occurs.

Internal clarity means that in order to counteract applied and sustained thought, one focuses the mind inwardly, abiding in equanimity, and because one is far removed from the defiled dharmas of applied and sustained thought, it is called internal clarity.
The mind becomes concentrated and unified means that at such a time, the mind abides in continuity, and the dharmas of applied and sustained thought never occur.
Free from applied thought and sustained thought means that one realizes the cessation of applied and sustained thought.
SamÄdhi means that for one who has attained the transmutation of the support, the mind abides in a single object.
Arisen means the joy and bliss born from samÄdhi, as explained above.

The second meditative absorption is the joy and bliss born of concentration, with the stilling of discursive thought and initial thought, and with internal clarity and confidence. It is the one-pointedness of mind that is based on this transformation.
The rest is as explained above.
Moreover, as the sutra says:

By abandoning joy, abiding in equanimity, mindfulness, and clear comprehension, and experiencing bliss with the body, the noble ones proclaim the attainment of the third meditative absorption, which is accomplished through equanimity, mindfulness, and bliss.

Abandoning joy means either taking as the object the teachings of the superior abandonment of desire for the second meditative absorption, or taking as the object the instructions on that, and seeing the faults in the characteristics of joy in the second meditative absorption.

Abiding in equanimity means that because one does not tolerate or is disgusted with the thoughts and intentions that have already arisen regarding joy, one abides in a non-defiled state of mental balance, mental uprightness, and mental immobility.
Mindfulness means not forgetting and clearly remembering the characteristics of the non-functioning of joy that have already been contemplated, causing joy to definitely not arise again.
Right knowledge refers to the case where, although one sometimes loses mindfulness and delight arises again, one correctly knows the characteristics of the delight that arises.

Bliss refers to the case where one who has already undergone the transformation of the basis, being free from delight and free from exertion, experiences a feeling of comfort and ease that is included in feeling.

Body refers to the case where one who has already undergone the transformation of the basis, whether it be the transformed consciousness or the Älaya consciousness, the nature of the mind is without distinction, and is generally referred to as the body.

Correct experience refers to the case where one who has already undergone the transformation of the basis is able to experience the body and cause the body to feel comfortable and at ease, and these are generally referred to as the correct experience of the bliss of the body.
This place of bliss is extremely tranquil, supremely subtle, and without compare above or below.
The noble ones refer to the Buddha and the disciples of the Buddha.
To proclaim means to reveal and establish.

To attain equanimity, mindfulness, and blissful abiding means that in this stage and above there is no wondrous bliss, and in the lower stages there is also no such supreme bliss and no equanimity and mindfulness as antidotes.
The third concentration is the basis of pleasure for the mind that abides in one-pointed concentration, with equanimity, mindfulness, and clear comprehension, free from joy.
The rest is as explained above.
Moreover, as the sutra says:
By eliminating pleasure, and having already eliminated suffering, joy, and worry, with equanimity and mindfulness purified, one abides in the fourth concentration.
Eliminating pleasure refers to entering the fourth concentration.
Having already eliminated suffering refers to entering the second concentration.
Having already eliminated joy refers to entering the third concentration.
Having already eliminated worry refers to entering the first concentration.

Neither suffering nor pleasure refers to the supreme and most excellent acceptance of the most tranquil and unshakable feeling that is included in the form realm, which is neither comfortable nor uncomfortable for one who has already transformed the basis.

The purity of equanimity means that because one transcends the three stages of initial and sustained thought, joy, and pleasure, all agitation ceases, and the mind becomes a state of evenness, uprightness, and stability without agitation.

The purity of mindfulness means that because one transcends the three stages of initial and sustained thought, joy, and pleasure, all agitation ceases, and the mind becomes a state of clarity without forgetfulness.
The fourth means that it is the fourth in the sequence of the meditative absorptions.

The meditative absorption means that because one delights in severing [afflictions], one relies on the equanimity, mindfulness, and purity that are neither painful nor pleasurable, and the mind abides in a single object with the support of the transformation of the basis.
The rest is as explained above.
Moreover, as the sutra says:

Because one completely transcends all conceptual thoughts of form, because one extinguishes conceptual thoughts of resistance, and because one does not attend to various conceptual thoughts, one enters the sphere of infinite space and abides in it in full.
All means all the characteristics.
Conceptual thoughts of form means conceptual thoughts of manifest form.
Completely transcending means being free from desire for them.
As the meaning of transcendence, the thought of resistance is extinguished and the various thoughts are not attended to. This should be understood in the same way.
The thought of resistance refers to the thought of the four great elements that are its basis and the thought of other derivative forms.

The various thoughts refer to the various thoughts included in the provisional forms such as long and short, coarse and fine, square and round, high and low, correct and incorrect, light and shadow, brightness and darkness, etc., within the four great elements and derivative forms.

When one correctly enters the sphere of infinite space, the thought of resistance is extinguished because it does not appear, and the various thoughts are not attended to. For this reason, one transcends all thoughts of form that are based on it.
Infinite means that the characteristics in the ten directions cannot be distinguished.
Space means the object of cognition that is the antidote to form.
The sphere of infinite space means the transformation of this place and the concentration that is able to rely on it.
The rest is explained as before.
Moreover, as the sutra says:
Transcending all the sphere of infinite space, entering the boundless consciousness, one abides in the fulfillment of the sphere of infinite consciousness.
Transcending all the sphere of infinite space means transcending both the neighboring stage and the fundamental stage.
Boundless consciousness means the consciousness that takes boundless space as its object now takes this as its object.
The sphere of infinite consciousness means the transformation of the basis and the concentration that can rely on it.
The rest is explained as before.
Moreover, as the sutra says:
Transcending all the sphere of infinite consciousness, entering the absence of even the slightest existence, one abides in the fulfillment of the sphere of nothingness.
Transcending all the sphere of infinite consciousness means transcending both the neighboring stage and the fundamental stage.

The absence of even the slightest existence means that when one seeks for objects in the sphere of consciousness, one finds not even the slightest existence. Apart from nothingness, there are no separate objects. This is because one only sees this object as extremely tranquil.
The sphere of nothingness refers to the basis of this sphere and the concentration that relies on it.
The rest is explained as before.
Moreover, as the sutra says:
Surpassing all the sphere of nothingness, entering the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, abiding in fulfillment.
Surpassing all the sphere of nothingness means surpassing both the preliminary concentration and the fundamental concentration.
Not perception means surpassing the perception of nothingness.

Not non-perception means that when seeking the object above the sphere of nothingness, one only obtains the extremely subtle mind and mental factors that take nothingness as their object, because one only sees this object as extremely tranquil.
The sphere of neither perception nor non-perception refers to the basis of this sphere and the concentration that relies on it.
The rest is explained as before.

As for establishing birth, this means that those who first cultivate the lower, middle, and upper first meditative absorption in this realm are later born in those places and experience the fruits of the three heavens, namely, the BrahmakÄyika gods, the Brahmapurohita gods, and the MahÄbrahmÄ gods.

If one skillfully cultivates the first meditative absorption with investigation and analysis, one is born in the MahÄbrahmÄ heaven, and there is no other superior place than that.ğŸ”½If one first cultivates the lower, middle, and upper second meditative absorption in this realm, one is later born in those places and experiences the fruits of the three heavens, namely, the ParÄ«ttÄbha gods, the ApramÄá¹‡Äbha gods, and the Ä€bhÄsvara gods.ğŸ”½If one first cultivates the lower, middle, and upper third meditative absorption in this realm, one is later born in those places and experiences the fruits of the three heavens, namely, the ParÄ«ttaÅ›ubha gods, the ApramÄá¹‡aÅ›ubha gods, and the Åšubhaká¹›tsna gods.

If one first cultivates the lower, middle, and upper fourth meditative absorption in this realm, one is later born in those places and experiences the fruits of the three heavens, namely, the Anabhraka gods, the Puá¹‡yaprasava gods, and the Brhatphala gods.

Because they are free from craving for form, there is no distinction of place. Although there are lower, middle, and upper causes of cultivation, they do not establish distinctions in the fruits of birth.
If one cultivates the sphere of infinite space in the lower, middle, and upper stages, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of the sphere of infinite space.
If one cultivates the sphere of infinite consciousness in the lower, middle, and upper stages, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of the sphere of infinite consciousness.
If one cultivates the sphere of nothingness in the lower, middle, and upper stages, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of the sphere of nothingness.

If one cultivates the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception in the lower, middle, and upper stages, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception.
Because of the distinction of the tranquility of concentration and the fulfillment or non-fulfillment of the duration of abiding, there is a distinction in them.
Moreover, because one often delights in the first concentration up to the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception, one does not exhaust one's life span and has an untimely death.
If one cultivates the lower worldly and undefiled fourth dhyÄna, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of the Pure Abode of No Affliction.

If one cultivates the middling, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of the Pure Abode of No Heat.ğŸ”½If one cultivates the upper, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of the Pure Abode of Wonderful Manifestation.
If one cultivates the upper superior, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of the Pure Abode of Wonderful Vision.
If one cultivates the upper utmost, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of the Pure Abode of Unimpeded Ultimate.

If one skillfully cultivates the bodhisattva's immeasurable and inconceivable samÄdhi, which leads to the fourth dhyÄna in the tenth ground, one receives the fruit of being born in the heaven of Great Freedom, surpassing the Pure Abode.
The pure refers to the ultimate first dhyÄna, which gives rise to all excellent virtues and swift spiritual powers.
Just as the characteristics of the pure first dhyÄna, the other dhyÄnas and formless states should be understood in the same way.
As for the distinctions in formlessness here, it refers to giving rise to the qualities such as liberation belonging to that stage.
Thus, the establishment of the various defilements and purities of those meditative absorptions and formless concentrations should be understood in this way.
Having explained the bases, now the factors of enlightenment will be explained.
The verse says:
There are many factors of enlightenment, the first being the thirty-seven.
The treatise says:

The various types of factors of enlightenment are numerous, but the first and foremost ones are thirty-seven, namely the four establishments of mindfulness and so forth, as explained in detail in the sutras.

As for the four establishments of mindfulness, the first is the establishment of mindfulness on the body. This refers to either taking the body as the object, or taking the teachings that are the dominant conditions for the body as the object, or taking the instructions on those as the object, and then, through the wisdom that arises from hearing, contemplating, and cultivating, either as mere images or as accomplished entities, well establishing mindfulness in the place of the object of the body, in order to attain liberation from the body.
As in the case of mindfulness of the body, so should it be understood in the case of mindfulness of feeling, mind, and dharmas.
The difference here is that each [mindfulness] should be applied as appropriate, up to the point of attaining liberation from the dharmas.
Moreover, in all cases, the mind and mental factors associated with mindfulness should be mentioned.

When thus arousing the mind of contemplation, there are four kinds of objects to be contemplated: 1. the object grasped by the mind, 2. the object experienced by the mind, 3. the object cognized by the mind, and 4. the object of the mind's defilement and purity.
The four right efforts are explained in detail in the sutras.
First, for the sake of eliminating the evil and unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen, one gives rise to desire, exertion, arouses right effort, exerts the mind, and upholds the mind.
Already arisen refers to those included in gross entanglements.
Evil and unwholesome dharmas refers to the afflictions and secondary afflictions of the desire realm that can give rise to evil conduct.
The meaning of evil and unwholesome has been explained above.
In order to abandon them means cultivating their antidotes in order to weaken them.
Desire means giving rise to the joy of realizing abandonment.
Exertion means not tolerating evil and returning to abandonment.
Arousing right effort means cultivating their antidotes firmly in many ways.
These last three phrases show the inferior antidote within the stage of non-determination, which is the wisdom of hearing and contemplation.
Encouraging the mind means cultivating the antidote and actualizing the wisdom of cultivation. If the mind is sunken and defiled by afflictions, one encourages the mind to rise.
Upholding the mind means when this antidote is being practiced, if the mind is floating and defiled by afflictions, one upholds the mind and brings it down.
Second, regarding the unarisen evil and unwholesome dharmas, for the sake of preventing their arising...
Unarisen means that which is included in the intense latent tendencies, the cause for giving rise to coarse entanglements.
For the sake of preventing their arising means in order to prevent the coarse entanglements from manifesting.ğŸ”½...
Desire to produce means to arouse the desire to realize [the good dharmas] that are not yet manifest.
Zeal means to abide without forgetting in order to prevent the non-manifestation [of the good dharmas], because one abides well in mindfulness.
Arousing right effort, exerting the mind, and holding the mind are all as explained above.
Third, for the sake of producing the good dharmas that have not yet arisen... and so on.
Not yet arisen means those that have not yet been attained.
Good dharmas refers to the three kinds of wisdom born from hearing, thinking, and cultivation, because they are called good due to their faultless meaning.
For the sake of producing means for the sake of attaining their arising.ğŸ”½Desire means to arouse the desire to realize [the good dharmas].
Zeal means seeking the correct means of embracing [the good dharmas].
Arousing right effort means cultivating them for a long time with sincerity and firmness.
The above three phrases show the antidotes for attaining the indeterminate stage and the good dharmas included in the wisdom of hearing and thinking, which are not yet manifest.
Exerting the mind and holding the mind means for the sake of attaining the wisdom of cultivation.
The rest is as explained above.

Fourth, for the already arisen wholesome dharmas, to cause them to abide, to cause them not to be forgotten, to cause them to be cultivated to completion, to cause them to be cultivated in excess, to cause them to increase, to cause them to be vast, to arouse desire, to exert effort, and so forth.
Already arisen means already attained.
To cause them to abide means the wisdom of hearing.
To cause them not to be forgotten means the wisdom of reflection.
To cause them to be cultivated to completion means the wisdom of cultivation.
These above three phrases show only guarding the wholesome already attained.
To cause them to be cultivated in excess, to cause them to increase, to cause them to be vast means, in order, not only giving rise to contentment with them.
To arouse desire means to give rise to the desire for realization.
The rest is as explained above.
The four bases of supernatural power are explained in detail in the sutras.
First, due to the predominance of desire, one attains samÄdhi.

For example, a practitioner who has cultivated superior wholesome roots in past lives, upon meeting a great teacher or a wise fellow practitioner, gives rise to faith and the desire to listen to the true Dharma.
Having listened to the true Dharma as desired, they gradually attain one-pointedness of mind.
Due to this desire, samÄdhi is accomplished.
In order to eliminate and prevent the arising of evil and unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen, they give rise to desire and uphold the mind;
if the wholesome dharmas that counteract them have not yet arisen, in order to cause them to arise;

if they have already arisen, in order to make them abide, not be forgotten, be cultivated to completion, be cultivated in abundance, increase, and expand, they give rise to desire and uphold the mind.
In this way, the practitioner further cultivates the eight kinds of practices of elimination: desire, exertion, faith, serenity, right mindfulness, right knowing, thought, and equanimity.
Due to this desire, samÄdhi is accomplished means attaining mastery over this.

As for the evil and unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen and those that have not yet arisen, the former refers to those that are included in the inferior fetters and those that are included in the weak and thin latent tendencies that have not yet been damaged or harmed.
As for causing them to be cut off and not arising, it is in order to be separated from the already arisen soft fetters and in order to damage the weak and thin latent tendencies.
Giving rise to desire and upholding the mind are explained in detail as before.
If those wholesome dharmas that are the antidotes to those [evil and unwholesome dharmas] have not yet arisen, it is in order to cause them to arise;

If they have already arisen, it is in order to make them abide, not be forgotten, be cultivated to completion, be cultivated in excess, increase, and expand. Giving rise to desire and upholding the mind are explained in detail as before, and one should understand [this].
As for the practitioner, it refers to one who practices in this way for a long time and abides in this way.
As for cultivating desire again, it is in order to realize their non-manifestation and damage.
As for exertion, it is because of desire that one gives rise to right effort in Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ.
Faith is the cause of the arising of desire. It is the definite faith in the harmfulness of that [desire] and in the benefits [of its abandonment].
Tranquility is the removal of the grossness and heaviness of body and mind through exertion, and the making of body and mind fit.
Right mindfulness is the non-forgetting of the mind in the guarding against sinking, floating, and the secondary defilements.
Right knowing is the discrimination and right knowing when the secondary defilements of sometimes forgetting mindfulness are in operation.
Thought is the making of the mind in calming and uplifting.
Equanimity is the nature of the mind that is neither defiled nor attached, that is equal, upright, and unmoving.
